title: Why do medina streets feel narrower than the map suggests?

sections.content: Medina streets measure about three meters across. They feel like one.

The buildings lean inward at upper floors — more shade at street level, more living space above. Covered passages called [sabats](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#sabat) turn streets into tunnels. The ratio of wall height to street width creates a canyon.

Then subtract the street itself. A three-meter passage is also a workshop, a display shelf, a parking spot for three motorcycles, a place where two men drink tea on plastic chairs. The navigable channel is whatever remains. Some days that's a meter.
European cities feel wider because they were redesigned for carriages and then cars. Medina streets were designed for pedestrians and pack animals. The dimensions are original.

shortAnswer: They were built for shoulders, not cars. Upper floors lean inward for shade, covered passages bridge the gap entirely, and the navigable space is whatever's left after workshops, parked motorcycles, and tea chairs claim their share.

title: Why does Marrakech feel hotter, slower, and louder than other cities?

sections.content: Marrakech sits at 450 meters on the [Haouz Plain](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#haouz), with the [High Atlas](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#high-atlas) to the south. Summer heat sets in May and doesn't lift until October. The city adapts to this. Shops close when outdoor temperatures pass 42°C. Streets empty. Activity resumes after sunset — dinner at 10pm is the first hour the air allows appetite.

Dense construction, hard surfaces, narrow streets — nothing absorbs sound. A motorcycle in an alley registers like a motorcycle in your room. The call to prayer from five nearby mosques arrives as overlapping waves. At night, when the heat releases from the walls and everyone is finally outside, the city is loudest because it's most alive.

shortAnswer: Marrakech sits on a red clay plain at 450 meters elevation, with the Atlas to the south and the Sahara beyond. Dense earthen walls absorb heat all day and radiate it back all night. Sound bounces between them. The city's rhythm follows the sun, not the clock.

title: Why does silence sound different here than at home?

sections.content: What passes for silence at home is the hum of insulation, sealed windows, HVAC systems, and sound-absorbing materials. In a medina riad, those sounds don't exist. [Tadelakt](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tadelakt), [zellige](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#zellige), concrete, and plaster reflect sound. Windows are single-pane or absent. When human noise stops, the building itself becomes audible — water in a pipe, cedarwood adjusting to the temperature drop, a rooster three streets away.

Marrakech has almost no ambient noise floor — no highway drone, no aircraft corridor, no electrical hum from dense infrastructure. When the motorcycles stop and the shops close, what remains is not silence but everything that was always there, finally audible.

shortAnswer: Thick earthen walls absorb high frequencies while allowing low ones through. Courtyard architecture creates acoustic wells. The absence of mechanical background noise — traffic, HVAC, appliances — reveals a different sonic baseline.

title: Why do riads feel cooler inside than outside, even without AC?

sections.content: The walls are forty to sixty centimeters of rammed earth or stone — dense enough to absorb heat all day and keep it out of the rooms behind them. By morning, after a desert night that can drop twenty degrees, the walls are cool again. The building resets every twenty-four hours.

The courtyard is the engine. Hot air rises from the sun-exposed center and escapes upward. Cooler air pulls in from the shaded rooms at ground level. A fountain adds evaporative cooling. Orange trees do the same through their leaves. The system runs on geometry and gravity.

illustrations.caption: Temperature and humidity zones inside a riad courtyard

shortAnswer: Thick earthen walls, a central courtyard pulling hot air upward, shade geometry, and a fountain adding moisture to the breeze. A riad can sit 10–15°C below street temperature without electricity. The building is the air conditioning.

title: Why do riads feel humid, especially at night?

sections.content: The courtyard fountain runs continuously. Evaporating water adds moisture to the air. Orange trees transpire. [Pisé](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#pise) and [tadelakt](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tadelakt) walls absorb and release moisture as humidity shifts — absorbing during hot dry days, releasing at night when temperatures drop.

Thick walls and small openings mean limited air exchange. The courtyard that cools by convection during the day becomes a moisture trap at night, when the loop weakens and humid air settles into ground-floor rooms.
Riad architecture trades humidity management for temperature management. Modern riads with mechanical ventilation handle both. Older ones make you choose.

shortAnswer: Courtyard fountains, thick earth walls that retain moisture, and limited air exchange create higher indoor humidity. At night, temperature drops cause condensation on cool wall surfaces.

title: Why do riad rooms only have windows facing inward?

sections.content: Privacy in Moroccan domestic life is a principle, not a preference. Windows face inward so no one on the street can see in. The family's life happens around the courtyard, visible only to the sky and the household.

The courtyard gives back: filtered light that shifts through the day, cool air drawn through natural convection, the sound of a fountain instead of motorcycles. The rooms are not dark. They're lit from a private sky.
The windowless exterior wall doubles as thermal mass — unbroken earth or stone, sixty centimeters thick. No window means no weak point in the insulation, no gap for street noise, no entry for dust.
Walk through any medina and look up. The street facades are blank. Behind every one is a courtyard open to the sky. The richest houses in Marrakech are invisible from the street.

shortAnswer: They have windows — facing the courtyard, not the street. No street-facing windows means no one can see in. The courtyard provides light, air, and the sound of water instead of traffic.

title: Why do shopkeepers shout but then ignore you when you enter?

sections.content: The shout is a numbers game. Of a hundred tourists passing the stall, perhaps five slow down, two enter, one might buy. The call has to be loud, personal, and relentless because the conversion rate is low. Five hundred competitors within shouting distance.

Once you've entered — crossed from the street into his territory — the dynamic inverts. Now you're the one who's curious. The shopkeeper who chased you in the street becomes the man who couldn't care less whether you buy. He drinks his tea. He lets you touch things. He waits for you to ask a price, because the person who asks first has already conceded interest.

The tourists who feel offended by the shouting were never going to buy. The ones who enter and get ignored often stay longer, touch more, and eventually ask. The shout filters for foot traffic. The silence filters for buyers.

shortAnswer: The shout gets you in the door. The ignoring gets you to stay.

title: Why does the city wake up late after lunch?

sections.content: Marrakech between 1pm and 4pm in summer is routinely above 42°C. Shops close because customers don't come. The main meal is lunch, between 1pm and 2pm, followed by rest.

Activity resumes around 4:30pm as shadows lengthen. By 7pm the streets are full. By 9pm the souks are at peak traffic. Dinner is 9:30 or 10pm. The most productive hours of the Marrakech day are between 6pm and midnight.

illustrations.caption: The daily activity rhythm of a Moroccan city — peaks at dawn and after dark

shortAnswer: Midday heat makes outdoor activity dangerous. The city follows a bimodal rhythm: morning activity, long midday rest, then a second peak from late afternoon into night.

title: Why are Moroccan houses inward-facing, not outward?

sections.content: From the street, every house looks the same. Plain walls, a wooden door, maybe a brass knocker. Open the door, and the house explodes inward — tiled courtyard, carved plaster, painted [cedarwood](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#cedar), a fountain surrounded by orange trees.

The principle is [hchouma](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#hchouma) — roughly, modesty. Displaying wealth on the exterior is considered tasteless. The street is shared public space. Inside, you can build a palace. Outside, the wall says nothing.

The most expensive riad in Marrakech is indistinguishable from its neighbors until you step inside. This also explains why your taxi driver can't find your riad. There are no visual cues — no house number that means anything, no nameplate, no distinguishing feature. You learn your own door by counting turns, not reading signs.

shortAnswer: Wealth is expressed inward, toward the courtyard, not toward the street. A plain exterior wall protects domestic life from the public gaze.

title: Why do so many streets end in walls or dead ends?

sections.content: The [cul-de-sac](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#derb) belongs to the families who live on it. It's semi-private space — an extension of the home. Children play there because through-traffic cannot reach them. The families share responsibility for sweeping it, lighting it, knowing who belongs.
Strangers who enter are noticed. Not confronted — watched. If you've wandered in by accident, someone will eventually appear at a doorway and redirect you.
For visitors, the dead end is a navigation problem. For residents, it's the reason the street is quiet, the children are safe, and the neighbors know each other's names.

shortAnswer: Dead ends mark the transition from public to semi-private residential territory. The medina's layout filters strangers away from homes.

title: Why do riad bathrooms sometimes smell?

sections.content: A water trap is a U-bend holding water between you and the sewer line. When the water evaporates — and in 45°C heat with guest bathrooms sitting empty between bookings, a trap dries out in days — sewer gas rises through the open pipe.

The other half of the problem is structural. Riads predate modern plumbing by centuries. A proper system needs vent stacks — vertical pipes carrying gases above the roofline. Installing one means drilling through walls built from [pisé](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#pise) and stone, sometimes sixty centimeters thick. Most renovators don't.

Medina drainage connects multiple properties to shared channels. A blockage three doors away pushes gases back through your drains. Your riad owner can maintain their plumbing perfectly and still inherit the smell from a neighbor who doesn't.

illustrations.caption: How a floor drain's water seal evaporates when a room goes unused
How a water trap seals sewer gas — and what happens when it dries out
Shared drainage channels connect multiple properties to a single outflow

shortAnswer: Dry water traps. Run the tap for ten seconds and the smell stops.

title: Why do cats outnumber dogs in these cities?

sections.content: Cats move through Marrakech's homes, restaurants, shops, and mosques without resistance. The medina has hundreds of thousands. Nobody counts precisely.

In 2025, the Moroccan government approved Draft Law 19.25, which would make it illegal to feed, shelter, or care for stray animals in public spaces — fines of 1,500 to 3,000 dirhams. The law targets dogs primarily but covers cats too. Animal welfare organizations have condemned it. The cultural practice of leaving food out for street cats — something Moroccans have done for generations — could technically become a criminal act.
Dogs exist in Morocco — outside the medina walls, in the Ville Nouvelle, in rural areas where they guard livestock and property.

shortAnswer: Cats are everywhere in the medina. Dogs are not — they exist outside the walls, in the Ville Nouvelle, in rural areas. In 2025, Draft Law 19.25 proposed criminalizing the feeding of stray animals in public spaces. Still under parliamentary review.

title: Why does tap water taste or smell weird sometimes?

sections.content: The treatment plant adds standard chlorine for disinfection, but the dominant taste is mineral, not chemical. Calcium and magnesium concentrations run higher than most northern European water. The mineral profile changes seasonally — heavier after rains, lighter in dry months.
In older riads, galvanized steel pipes installed decades ago leach trace minerals as they corrode. Rooftop storage tanks can develop sediment if not cleaned regularly.
Sidi Ali and Sidi Harazem are the local bottled brands — both Atlas spring water, both about 5 dirhams for a liter and a half. Plenty of Moroccans drink the tap water daily.

shortAnswer: It's safe. Morocco's tap water comes from Atlas limestone aquifers — high in calcium and magnesium, mineral-heavy in a way that reads as flat or chalky. In older buildings, decades-old pipes add their own character.

title: Why do meals feel later than you're used to?

sections.content: The day's main meal is lunch — between 1pm and 3pm — substantial: [tagine](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tagine), [couscous](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#couscous), salads, bread, fruit. After lunch, rest. After rest, the late afternoon revival. By the time the heat breaks, the evening prayer is called, and tea is served, it's 9pm.
Cooking heats the house. In a climate where staying cool is the priority, one hot meal in the early afternoon and one late meal when the air has cooled makes thermal sense.

[Ramadan](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#ramadan) shifts everything further. Iftar happens at sunset, around 7:30pm in summer. The real dinner follows at 10 or 11pm. A pre-dawn meal, suhoor, at 3 or 4am.

shortAnswer: Lunch lands around 1:30–3pm, dinner at 9 or 10. The schedule follows the heat — you eat after it breaks, not when the clock says so.

title: Why do people eat bread with everything, even sweet things?

sections.content: [Khobz](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#khobz) — round, dense, slightly chewy — is baked in communal ovens called [ferrans](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#ferran). Every neighborhood has one. Families prepare dough at home, mark their loaves, and send them to the ferran. The baker knows every family by their mark.
The bread tears, scoops, and delivers. No fork touches the tagine. It acts as plate, spoon, and napkin.
Bread is the cheapest calorie available — a family of four can eat for 3 to 5 dirhams of flour per day. A dish that looks like it serves two feeds six, because the bread absorbs the sauce.
Sweet dishes get the same treatment. Honey, [amlou](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#amlou), olive oil with cumin — all eaten with bread.

shortAnswer: Bread is the utensil. Moroccan [khobz](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#khobz) tears into scoops for tagines and salads. The cuisine is built around communal eating from shared dishes, and bread is the tool that makes it work.

title: Why doesn't mint tea taste like mint tea everywhere?

sections.content: [Atay nana](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#atay): Chinese gunpowder green tea brewed strong, combined with fresh spearmint (nana, not peppermint) and roughly one tablespoon of sugar per glass. Some families use more.

The pouring from height — sometimes two feet above the glass — aerates the liquid and creates a thin layer of foam. The first glass is poured back into the pot and re-poured two or three times until the consistency is right. Each of the three rounds tastes different: the first mild, the second strong, the third sweet.
The preparation takes ten minutes, the three rounds take thirty. During that time you are sitting, talking, and being hosted.

shortAnswer: Moroccan mint tea is Chinese gunpowder green tea with fresh spearmint and a lot of sugar, brewed and poured from height to create froth. It's a prepared beverage with a specific technique, not mint steeped in hot water.

title: Why does the ground feel warmer underfoot than the air?

sections.content: Dense materials — stone, brick, rammed earth, concrete — absorb solar energy all day and release it over hours. Air temperature drops as soon as the sun goes down. Ground temperature follows six to eight hours later.

In the medina, the effect compounds. Heated from below by the ground, from both sides by the walls, and from above by the terrace overhead. The air temperature might read 30°C. Your body, absorbing radiant heat from every surface, feels 38.

shortAnswer: Stone and clay surfaces absorb solar radiation all day and re-radiate it upward. In the medina, narrow streets trap ground-level heat. Air temperature at head height can be several degrees cooler than at foot level.

title: Why does heat feel more exhausting here than elsewhere?

sections.content: The city sits on clay and limestone that reflects solar radiation upward. Walls absorb heat all morning and re-radiate through the afternoon. You're heated from above, below, and both sides. The effective temperature can be ten degrees higher than the shade reading.
Humidity is often below 20% in summer. Sweat evaporates so fast you don't feel wet, which makes you underestimate water loss. Dehydration arrives before you notice.
At 450 meters, UV radiation is stronger than at sea level. The combination — radiant heat, invisible dehydration, elevated UV — produces exhaustion that temperature alone doesn't explain.
Two liters of water a day is a minimum. Three is better. The thirst signal arrives too late.

shortAnswer: Marrakech heat combines high temperature, low humidity (accelerating dehydration), reflected heat from earth walls, altitude (450m), and strong UV. Multiple stressors operate simultaneously.

title: Why do cockroaches show up even in clean places?

sections.content: Marrakech's medina is roughly 30,000 people per square kilometer. Buildings share walls. Drainage channels connect entire neighborhoods underground. A cockroach born in one building has physical access to every building on the same drainage line.

The species is most likely Periplaneta americana. It thrives between 25°C and 33°C — which describes Marrakech for seven months of the year. It can flatten its body to fit through a gap the width of two coins.

A single riad can spray, seal, and sanitize — and the roaches return through the shared drain from next door. Effective control requires every building on the same drainage line to treat simultaneously. In a medina where some buildings are abandoned and some owners live in Casablanca, coordination is impossible.

shortAnswer: Cockroaches travel through the medina's interconnected drainage, shared walls, and century-old construction. A cockroach in a clean riad came from the infrastructure below, not from the kitchen.

title: Why does walking 500 meters feel like 2 kilometers?

sections.content: The shortest route between two points involves fifteen or twenty turns, each requiring a decision with no signage. Decision fatigue adds cognitive load that your brain interprets as distance.

Walking pace drops from a European-sidewalk average of 5 km/h to about 2 km/h — navigating around people, motorcycles, handcarts, cats, and donkeys. Five hundred meters at 2 km/h takes fifteen minutes.
Every meter presents new input — smells, sounds, visual detail, people requiring spatial negotiation. The information density per meter is five or ten times higher than a typical city street.
The five-minute claim from your host is their five minutes. They know the route, skip the decisions, walk at medina pace without the cognitive overhead.

shortAnswer: Medina streets curve, branch, and change width constantly. Without straight sightlines, your brain can't estimate distance. Every turn resets your mental map. Add heat, crowds, and uneven ground, and perceived distance stretches.

title: Why does Google Maps mislead you more here than at home?

sections.content: The [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) is a three-dimensional network where streets pass under buildings, split into levels, change width from two meters to forty centimeters, and sometimes exist as passages through private homes that are open during the day and locked at night.
GPS signals bounce off high walls, creating positioning errors of ten to thirty meters. In a city where parallel streets can be five meters apart, a thirty-meter error puts you on the wrong street.

Street View cars can't enter streets narrower than their wheelbase — which excludes most of the medina. User-contributed data is patchy. Entire passages are missing. Others are marked as through-streets but have been bricked shut for years.

Locals navigate by landmarks: the fountain, the mosque, the bakery smell, the blue door. "Go toward the smell of bread, turn left at the mosque, ask again." This system has worked for a thousand years.

shortAnswer: Google Maps assumes grid-based, car-navigable streets. The medina has none. Covered passages, stairs, 3D elevation changes don't appear on the map. GPS signal bounces between walls with 10–30 meter errors.

title: Why do locals turn right where tourists go left?

sections.content: The wider street is not necessarily the faster route — it's the commercial route, congested. The narrow dark passage is the residential shortcut, empty because it goes nowhere a tourist wants to be.

The navigation is social. Doors that look closed are actually open. Passages that look private are shared shortcuts tolerated by the families who live along them. A resident nods at the woman on the step and walks through what you'd perceive as her front garden. You can't follow this route because you don't have the social permission.
When a Moroccan says "it's close," they mean close by their route. When they say "straight," they mean the general direction, not a literal straight line.

shortAnswer: Locals navigate by landmarks, sounds, smells, and social memory — not maps. They know which alleys connect, which dead ends have shortcuts, and which routes avoid afternoon sun.

title: Why do shop aisles seem emptier but more crowded?

sections.content: A European shop puts goods on shelves around the perimeter with an empty aisle in the center. A [souk](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#souk) shop stacks goods on every surface including the ceiling, with the shopkeeper on a raised platform in the middle.

The density forces engagement — you can't browse at arm's length. You end up touching, picking up, turning things over. Every interaction is at conversation distance, which is how Moroccan commerce works.

shortAnswer: Souk shops stack merchandise floor to ceiling with the shopkeeper sitting in the middle. The browsable space is whatever remains — often less than a square meter. Two people is a crowd because the stall was designed for one customer at a time.

title: Why does it feel rude to refuse tea but you don't want any?

sections.content: [Tea](https://slowmorocco.com/story/the-mint-tea-ritual) in Morocco creates a space — ten minutes, three glasses — where two people sit as equals. Business may happen in that space. It may not. The tea is not a trap. It's a protocol.

Leaving after the first glass causes no offense. Leaving before the first glass is finished is rude. Staying for all three and buying nothing is entirely acceptable. Tea is a cost of doing business, not an invoice.

shortAnswer: Tea is a hospitality protocol, not a transaction. Accepting acknowledges the social relationship. Refusing signals rejection of the person, not the drink.

title: Why does time feel elastic here?

sections.content: Official time — flight schedules, government offices — runs on the clock. Social time — everything else — runs on context. A meeting at 10am means the meeting begins when the relevant people arrive and preceding obligations have been fulfilled.

Finishing the conversation you're already in — even if it makes you late to the next one — means respect for the person in front of you. Cutting short a tea to arrive on time for an appointment would be rude to the tea host.

The five daily prayers are fixed to the sun, not the clock — they shift by minutes every day. Shops close for prayer, reopen, close for heat, reopen for evening. The rhythm is solar and social, not mechanical.

shortAnswer: Morocco operates on relationship time, not clock time. Meetings start when everyone arrives. Meals happen when food is ready. Schedules serve social harmony, not efficiency.

title: Why does everything feel more intense at dusk?

sections.content: The city is built from materials that respond to low-angle light. [Pisé](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#pise), [tadelakt](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tadelakt), and sandstone contain iron oxides that glow red and orange when the sun drops below thirty degrees above the horizon. The same walls that look beige at noon become luminous at 6pm.
Desert climates lose heat rapidly once direct sun stops. A twenty-degree swing between 3pm and 9pm is normal. Relief after sustained heat stress produces a heightened sensory state.
Dusk is when people emerge. The streets fill. The food stalls light their gas lamps. The square transforms from a hot empty plaza into smoke, music, grilling meat, and drumming.

shortAnswer: Dusk triggers a convergence: heat breaks, the call to prayer sounds, street food fires up, people emerge from afternoon rest, and golden light transforms the red earth architecture. Five sensory shifts within one hour.

title: Why do Moroccan cities feel layered, not organized?

sections.content: A [Roman](https://slowmorocco.com/story/the-roman-bath) column embedded in a wall. A French balcony grafted onto an older house. A satellite dish bolted to a minaret. Nothing has been demolished. Everything has been absorbed.

The street you walk on may be a meter above the original ground level — built up by centuries of debris, collapsed walls, and new foundations laid over old ones. Unlike European cities periodically leveled by fire or planning, Moroccan medinas were never wiped clean. Each era added to what was already there.

shortAnswer: Moroccan cities were built incrementally over centuries without master plans. Roman, Arab, Berber, French, and modern layers coexist. A single wall may contain 12th-century stone, 18th-century plaster, and 2020s wiring.

title: Why do medina walls feel like memory?

sections.content: Every repair is visible. Each owner used a different mix, a different color, a different hand. Rain carves channels. [Salt](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#efflorescence) pushes plaster off in sheets. The layer beneath is always a different era. A single wall can show three generations of maintenance.

New construction in the medina looks wrong — fresh plaster, sharp edges, uniform color. Every other surface carries the weight of use. Smoke, moisture, oil from hands, weather. The new wall hasn't earned its surface yet.

shortAnswer: Medina walls are made of tadelakt, pisé, and earth plaster that erode, patch, and re-erode visibly. Every repair leaves a mark. Walls display their own history — cracks, color shifts, patches — like geological strata.

title: Why do neighborhoods have their own invisible rules?

sections.content: Medina neighborhoods — [hawma](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#hawma) or [derb](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#derb) — are self-governing units with codes that predate municipal law. Families on a dead-end street share responsibility for cleaning, lighting, maintenance, and surveillance.

A family that doesn't sweep their section of the alley will hear about it from the neighbor's look. Noise, unfamiliar faces — all regulated by the fact that everyone can see everyone else. Privacy inside the home is absolute. Behavior in the shared passage is subject to collective judgment.
One derb is tidy, quiet, flowers on the wall. The next is louder, more commercial. The difference is not wealth — it's social cohesion.

shortAnswer: Each derb has unwritten social codes managed by long-term residents. Who parks where, when noise is acceptable, how strangers are received — negotiated communally, not legally.

title: Why do markets feel alive but not loud?

sections.content: Markets are zoned by trade, each with its own acoustic signature. Brass workers' hammering is rhythmic and localized. The leather dyers' section is quiet — chemical work. Spice merchants murmur. Textile sellers negotiate at conversation volume. You move through acoustic neighborhoods.

Souk roofing — reed mats, corrugated metal, wooden lattice — diffuses sound. Open-air sections vent noise upward. Narrow streets prevent lateral travel. You hear the stall in front and behind, not two aisles over.
The rhythm is human. Sound rises and falls with activity. Morning is quiet. Midday peaks. Afternoon drops. Evening explodes.

shortAnswer: Souk acoustics absorb sound through textiles, leather, and narrow geometry. Sellers project voice directionally. The overall volume is dense but layered — each sound occupies its own spatial zone.

title: Why is there white powdery stuff on the walls?

sections.content: Groundwater carries dissolved minerals upward through porous earth walls by capillary action. When the water reaches the surface and evaporates, the minerals stay behind as white crust.

Medina buildings sit on ground that has been wet for centuries. Pisé and traditional lime plaster are breathable — they absorb moisture and release it. When the moisture carries dissolved minerals, those minerals accumulate on the surface.

Modern cement plaster makes it worse. Cement is not breathable. It traps moisture behind the surface, building pressure until the plaster cracks or pops off. Traditional lime plaster lets the wall breathe, sacrificing appearance for structural health.
There is no permanent fix in the medina. The ground is wet and the walls are earth. The salt bloom is a symptom of buildings that are still breathing.

title: Is Marrakech safe after the 2023 earthquake?

sections.content: Magnitude 6.8, September 2023, the strongest in Morocco in over a century. Nearly 3,000 people died. The devastation was in the mountains, not the medina.

Marrakech's thick-walled construction proved largely resilient. The [Koutoubia](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#koutoubia)'s 12th-century minaret survived intact. Most riads sustained cosmetic damage — cracked plaster, shifted tiles. By early 2024, the medina was largely repaired and fully operational.

The mountain villages are a different story. Amizmiz, Moulay Brahim, Talat N'Yacoub — communities where traditional stone houses collapsed. Reconstruction continues. The mountain communities depend on the economic activity visitors bring — trekking, guesthouse stays, guided walks.

shortAnswer: Yes. The medina was shaken but not destroyed. Most riads sustained cosmetic damage and have been repaired. The souks never closed. The lasting devastation is in remote mountain villages, not the city.

title: What should I wear in Marrakech?

sections.content: Cover your shoulders, cover your knees. The medina is a residential neighborhood and the people who live here are conservative.

Loose linen or cotton trousers, a shirt that covers the shoulders, shoes you can walk on uneven stone in for hours. Headscarves are not required for non-Muslim women. Men in shorts above the knee in the medina get looks.
A light scarf serves triple duty: sun protection, shoulder coverage for sacred spaces, and a dust filter in the souks.
Shoes matter more than clothes. The medina floor is uneven stone, often wet, sometimes covered in vegetable matter or motor oil. Sneakers work best.

shortAnswer: Shoulders and knees covered. Loose, light fabrics. Closed-toe shoes that survive cobblestones. Women don't need to cover their hair. The dress code is as much about heat management as culture.

title: Why does the first night in a riad feel unsettling?

sections.content: Your nervous system is calibrated to the ambient noise of home — refrigerator hum, traffic drone, climate control. In a [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) [riad](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#riad), those sounds don't exist. The resulting silence triggers alert mode.

The sounds that do come arrive without context. A cat screaming on the rooftop — mating calls that sound like a child in distress. The call to prayer at 4:30am from a minaret you can't see. Your brain, unable to categorize these, files them as threat.

Riad courtyards are lit by the sky, and at night the sky is the only light source. Your room opens directly onto the courtyard, often without a solid door. The boundary between sleeping space and open courtyard is permeable.
If you've flown from North America, jet lag weaponizes all of it — cortisol peaks at the wrong time. The second night is better. The third night you sleep through the call to prayer.

shortAnswer: Unfamiliar silence, unidentifiable sounds, open courtyard shadows, and the call to prayer at 4am. Your brain is scanning an unknown environment. By the third night, it stands down.

title: Why are there monkeys in Marrakech, and should I interact with them?

sections.content: The Barbary macaque — Macaca sylvanus — is the only primate native to Africa that also lives in Europe. Its home is the Atlas Mountains, where wild populations live in cedar and oak forests around Azrou and Ifrane. Morocco has an estimated 8,000 to 10,000 left. The number is falling.

The ones in Marrakech were taken from the wild as infants. Poachers capture babies by driving mothers from the troop — sometimes killing them. Canine teeth are pulled or filed down. The animals are dressed, chained, and used as photo props. Every photo taken funds the capture of the next infant.
The Barbary macaque is listed as Endangered on the IUCN Red List. Capturing or trading them is illegal under Moroccan law and under CITES. Enforcement is inconsistent.

shortAnswer: The Barbary macaques in Jemaa el-Fna were taken illegally from the wild as infants, had their teeth pulled, and are chained as photo props. Paying for a photo funds the next capture. Wild populations live in the cedar forests near Azrou and Ifrane.

title: Why do women grab your hand and start drawing henna on it?

sections.content: The paste stains in seconds and can't be wiped off without leaving a mark. The price, unquoted before the grab, appears after the design is complete: 200 to 500 dirhams. Protest and it goes up. Other women surround you.

Henna art — real henna art — is a skilled practice with deep roots in Moroccan celebration. Brides receive elaborate designs over hours, applied by specialists. What happens in the square is a transaction using henna as the prop.
Hands in pockets or visibly occupied reads as unavailable. Eye contact plus slowing down reads as interest. Movement is the clearest signal.
Most riads can arrange a proper session — an artist who shows designs, agrees a price, and takes an hour. Budget 150 to 300 dirhams for hands.

shortAnswer: Once the paste is on your skin, you're expected to pay 200–500 dirhams. The paste stains in seconds. Pull your hand back before it touches skin. Real henna art happens in completely different settings.

title: How does a Moroccan hammam actually work?

sections.content: Three rooms. The first — cool — is where you acclimatize. The second — warm — is where you soak, lather with savon beldi (black olive soap), and let the steam open your pores. The third — hot — is the furnace room. Ten to twenty minutes in each.
After steaming, an attendant uses a kessa — a coarse exfoliating glove — to scrub every surface of your body. Hard. The dead skin comes off in visible rolls.
Most people bring: a bucket (or buy one outside for 15 dirhams), savon beldi, a kessa glove, shampoo, a towel, clean underwear, and flip-flops. Everything gets wet.
Entry to a local hammam: 15 to 20 dirhams. A scrub from an attendant: 50 to 80 dirhams extra. Most people leave another 20 to 30 as a tip.

shortAnswer: Three rooms, each hotter than the last. You steam, lather with black olive soap, and someone scrubs your skin with a coarse glove until visible rolls of dead skin come off. Locals do this weekly. Entry: 15–20 dirhams.

title: What's the difference between a local hammam and a spa hammam?

sections.content: A neighborhood hammam is a public facility. Men and women use it at separate times. You undress in a shared changing area, sit on the floor next to strangers, and the attendant scrubs you in full view of everyone.
Spa hammams offer private treatment rooms, robes, slippers, ambient lighting, English-speaking staff. Men and women can book together. The scrub is gentler. The products are branded.

The neighborhood hammam is a social institution — women exchange news, negotiate marriages, settle disputes. The communal nudity is the one space where social hierarchy dissolves. The spa version is a service. The local version is a culture.
Most people who've done both recommend the spa first to learn the mechanics, then the neighborhood hammam for the real thing.

shortAnswer: A local hammam costs 20 dirhams. A spa hammam costs 400–800. The water is the same temperature. The soap is the same. The difference: privacy, comfort, and the absence of awkwardness. The spa removes the friction. The local hammam is the friction.

title: Should I take a calèche ride, and are the horses okay?

sections.content: SPANA — the Society for the Protection of Animals Abroad — has been in Morocco since 1925. Their Marrakech clinic is the biggest in the world — around 1,500 donkeys, mules, and horses come through every month. Since 1988, every calèche horse is inspected three times a year plus spot checks, covering nutrition, hoof care, harness fit, and overall condition.
Nine water troughs on the main carriage routes, cleaned and refilled twice daily. Before the troughs, dehydration was one of the biggest welfare problems.
Annual Calèche of the Year Awards since 1996 — best horse, best carriage, best effort. Winners get copper plaques on the front of their carriage. Look for the plaques when you choose a carriage.
Prices are printed on a sticker on every carriage. A circuit of the medina walls runs about an hour. Agree the price and route before you get in.

shortAnswer: The blue SPANA band on a horse's ankle means it's been veterinary-inspected and microchipped. SPANA has run the calèche licensing scheme since 1988, with health checks three times a year and nine water troughs across the city.

title: Who has right of way in a medina alley?

sections.content: Weight and momentum win. A donkey carrying two hundred kilos can't stop or reverse easily. You can. A motorcycle at speed in a narrow passage has less ability to brake than you have to press yourself against the wall.
A short horn beep means "I'm behind you, move slightly left or right." The correct response is a half-step to either side without turning around. The motorcycle passes with centimeters to spare.

A handcart operator shouts "balak!" — watch out. A donkey handler clicks or hisses. A cyclist says nothing. Your job as a pedestrian: walk at a steady pace, keep roughly to the right, don't make sudden lateral moves.
Intersections have no rules except eye contact. Whoever arrives first goes first. If a donkey is involved, the donkey goes.

shortAnswer: No traffic signs, no lanes, no formal rules. An unwritten hierarchy runs on physics: laden donkeys first, then handcarts, then motorcycles, then pedestrians. A horn beep means shift slightly — not freeze.

title: Why is it so loud in the medina at night?

sections.content: The medina is a residential neighbourhood that also happens to be a tourist destination, a commercial district, and an event venue. Riads converted into restaurants with live music. Rooftop bars with speakers. The density that makes the medina beautiful makes it acoustically porous.

Law 11-03 (Article 47) states that noise likely to cause nuisance must be eliminated or reduced. Penalties: 1,000 to 20,000 dirhams, doubled for repeat offences. The Penal Code (Article 609) addresses nocturnal disturbances.
Speak to your riad host. They know the rhythms — which nights events are scheduled, which rooms face away from the source. Some hosts provide earplugs. Many will move you to a different room.

shortAnswer: Stone walls carry sound. Courtyards amplify it. And there's no buffer between a wedding next door and your pillow. Morocco's Law 11-03 protects residents from noise nuisance — fines up to 40,000 dirhams — but enforcement works at neighbourhood speed.

title: Can you file a noise complaint in Morocco?

sections.content: Law 11-03 (Dahir n°1-03-59, 12 May 2003) — Article 47: noise and vibrations likely to cause nuisance must be eliminated or reduced. Fines: 1,000 to 20,000 dirhams. Repeat offence: 1,000 to 40,000 dirhams, plus one to thirty days imprisonment.
Penal Code, Article 609, paragraph 23 — addresses noise, disturbances, or nocturnal gatherings troubling the tranquillity of inhabitants. Fine: 10 to 120 dirhams.
Law 15-91 (Dahir n°1-91-112, 26 June 1995) — prohibits smoking in public spaces. A 2024 parliamentary proposal sought to expand scope and increase penalties to 300–600 dirhams.

The complaint process: first the moqaddem (neighbourhood representative), then a written complaint to the arrondissement, then the procureur du Roi. A constat d'huissier (bailiff's sworn report) with timestamps strengthens any case.
The implementing regulations — specific noise thresholds — are still being developed. The framework exists. Documentation and persistence are your strongest tools.

shortAnswer: Yes. Law 11-03 (Article 47) prohibits noise nuisance — fines up to 40,000 dirhams. Penal Code Article 609 addresses nocturnal disturbances. Complaint chain: moqaddem → arrondissement → procureur du Roi.

title: What is the Police Touristique and how do I reach them?

sections.content: The Brigade Touristique handles theft, harassment, vendor disputes, overcharging, and any situation where a tourist needs police intervention. Officers speak multiple languages — typically French, English, sometimes Spanish. They operate in plainclothes and uniform.

In Marrakech, the station is on Place Jemaa el-Fna, near the post office, on the Koutoubia side. Direct line: +212 524 384 601. 24-hour line: +212 524 888 680. National emergency: 19 (police in cities), 177 (Gendarmerie outside cities), 150 (ambulance), 15 (fire). From mobile: 112.

Tourist Police units also operate in Fes, Casablanca, Rabat, Tangier, and Agadir. Smaller cities like Essaouira and Chefchaouen have police presence but may not have dedicated tourist brigade offices — your riad is often the fastest route to assistance.

If your phone is stolen, file a report (procès-verbal) at the station — you'll need your passport. The report is essential for insurance claims. The Arabic phrase "Ha-shooma!" — shame on you — said loudly, draws immediate attention from locals who will intervene.

title: Can you photograph people in Morocco?

sections.content: The rule: **ask first.** In Darija, *nqder nsewwrek?* or pointing at your camera and raising your eyebrows. Most people say yes. Some say no. Both deserve respect.
**Women and children should generally not be photographed.** In conservative neighborhoods, photographing a woman without consent causes genuine offence. With children, parents may not be present.

Snake charmers, [henna ladies](https://derb.so/questions/why-henna-ladies-grab-your-hand), musicians, water sellers in traditional dress — they expect payment for photos. 10–20 MAD. This is their livelihood.
Shopkeepers and [artisans](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#maalem) are often happy to be photographed, especially if you've bought something or shown genuine interest.

title: What is Ramadan, and how does it affect your visit?

sections.content: [Ramadan](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#ramadan) is the ninth month of the Islamic lunar calendar. For 29 or 30 days, Muslims fast from dawn to sunset: no food, no water, no smoking. Observed by the vast majority of Moroccans.
In **2026**, Ramadan falls approximately **18 February – 19 March**. In **2027**, around **7 February – 8 March**. Exact dates are confirmed by moon sighting — sometimes just a day before.
**Most businesses in urban areas stay open.** Restaurants serving tourists continue to operate. Riads serve breakfast and lunch. Museums keep their hours. The idea that Morocco shuts down is a myth.

Energy dips in the afternoon. Around 30 minutes before sunset, businesses may close briefly for *ftour* — dates, milk, and [harira](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#harira) soup. By an hour after sunset, streets fill and cafés overflow. Ramadan evenings are some of the most atmospheric nights in Morocco.

Visitors aren't expected to fast. Eating, drinking, or smoking in public during daylight draws attention. Your riad courtyard or a tourist restaurant — fine. Walking through the [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) eating a sandwich — not.

shortAnswer: The Islamic month of fasting from dawn to sunset. In 2026: approximately 18 February – 19 March. Most tourist businesses stay open. Visitors aren't expected to fast — just be discreet about eating and drinking in public during daylight.

title: What happens during Eid al-Adha in Morocco?

The sacrifice happens on the morning of Eid itself. In a [riad](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#riad) in the medina, you'll hear it and smell it. In **2026**, expected around **27 May**. In **2027**, around **17 May**.
**Most urban businesses remain open**, though many close for part of the morning. Tourist-facing restaurants and riads continue to operate. The festive atmosphere extends for about a week.
If invited to share a meal during Eid al-Adha, say yes.

shortAnswer: Morocco's most important religious holiday. Families sacrifice a sheep. In 2026: around 27 May. Most urban businesses stay open but may close for part of the morning. The holiday lasts two to three days.

title: Should you take your shoes off when entering a Moroccan home?

sections.content: When entering a Moroccan home, shoes come off at the door. Same for most [riads](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#riad) when stepping onto carpeted areas or living rooms. Your host may offer slippers.

[Medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) streets are dusty, sometimes worse. [Zellige](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#zellige) tilework and handwoven [rugs](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#kilim) are kept meticulously clean. Street shoes crossing that threshold signals a lack of respect for the space.

**Mosques require shoe removal.** Non-Muslims cannot enter most mosques in Morocco. The [Hassan II Mosque](https://slowmorocco.com/places/hassan-ii-mosque) in Casablanca is the exception — guided tours daily.
In shops, shoes stay on. If unsure, watch your host. If their feet are bare or in slippers, yours should be too.

shortAnswer: In homes, riad living areas, and mosques — yes. The cue is visible: a row of shoes near the door, a mat, or your host in slippers. Shops and commercial spaces don't expect it.

title: How do you eat from a shared tagine without embarrassing yourself?

sections.content: **Right hand.** The left is considered unclean. This applies whether using bread or fingers. If you're left-handed, the effort is noticed and appreciated.

**Bread is the utensil.** Tear off a small piece of [khobz](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#khobz) and use it to pinch meat, scoop sauce, or grab vegetables. Forks and spoons are available in most restaurants.

**Eat from your section.** The geometry: eat from the area directly in front of you, working inward. If your host pushes a choice piece toward you, that's generosity. [Couscous](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#couscous) follows the same principle — shape a small ball from your section.

Before the meal, someone may bring a basin and kettle to wash your hands. Hold your hands over the basin while water is poured. [Mint tea](https://derb.so/questions/why-mint-tea-tastes-different) follows.
A hand placed over your heart with *baraka l'laoufik* (bless you) signals you're full.

shortAnswer: Right hand, bread as utensil, eat from the section directly in front of you. Reaching across the dish is the one thing that gets noticed.

title: Why does Agadir look nothing like other Moroccan cities?

sections.content: On 29 February 1960, at 11:40pm, the earthquake destroyed Agadir. Between 12,000 and 15,000 people died. The old [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina), the Kasbah, the residential quarters — all gone.

The new city was rebuilt two kilometres south, designed by Moroccan and French architects including Jean-François Zevaco and Elie Azagury, with consultation from Le Corbusier. Wide streets. Low-rise reinforced concrete. Seismic standards that didn't exist before 1960.
The only remnant of old Agadir is the restored Kasbah wall — Agadir Oufella — which reopened in 2024. The inscription above its gate reads in Arabic and Dutch: *God, the Nation, the King.*
What Agadir has: a 10-kilometre beach, Souk El Had (purpose-built, covering several city blocks), a thriving port, and roughly 300 days of sunshine.

shortAnswer: A 5.8-magnitude earthquake in 1960 destroyed the city in 15 seconds, killing a third of the population. Agadir was rebuilt from scratch two kilometres south — wide boulevards, modern architecture, seismic standards. No ancient medina. No historic riads.

title: What is there to do in Agadir if you're not a beach person?

sections.content: The honest answer: Agadir is a base, not a destination in the way [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech) or Fes are destinations. Its strength is what's around it.

**Souk El Had** is the city's commercial heart — one of the largest markets in North Africa, sprawling across multiple blocks with over 3,000 shops. It's modern, organised, and genuinely useful for spices, argan products, and leatherwork. Less atmospheric than a [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) souk, but the prices are more transparent and the range is enormous.

**Agadir Oufella** — the restored hilltop Kasbah — reopened in 2024 after a careful heritage project that preserved what the [1960 earthquake](https://derb.so/questions/why-does-agadir-look-nothing-like-other-moroccan-cities) left standing. The view from the top spans the entire bay. At night, the walls are illuminated and the Arabic inscription — *God, Country, King* — glows across the hillside.

The real draw is the **Souss-Massa region** radiating outward. [Taghazout](https://derb.so/questions/is-taghazout-still-a-surf-village) is 20 minutes north — Morocco's surf coast. Paradise Valley in the foothills of the High Atlas is an hour inland, with natural swimming pools carved into canyon rock. Tiznit, an hour south, is the centre of Moroccan silver jewellery. Taroudant — *little Marrakech* — sits in the Souss plain surrounded by intact ramparts and a working [souk](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#souk) that sees almost no tourists.

For food: Agadir's port area serves some of the freshest and cheapest seafood in Morocco. Grilled sardines, calamari, sole — pulled off the boats that morning. The city also sits at the heart of the argan-producing region. The Arganier Museum on the road to Taghazout documents the tree, the oil, and the cooperative system that produces it.
Agadir rewards people who use it as a launchpad. Stay on the coast, eat well, and radiate outward. The interesting Morocco is 30 minutes in every direction.

shortAnswer: Agadir works best as a base. The city itself offers Souk El Had (one of North Africa's largest markets), the restored Kasbah hilltop, and excellent port-side seafood. The real draw is what's around it: Taghazout's surf coast (20 min), Paradise Valley (1 hour), Tiznit's silver market, and Taroudant's unwalled medina. Agadir rewards people who radiate outward.

title: Is Taghazout still a surf village, or has it changed?

sections.content: Both. That's the tension, and everyone who's been here longer than a week can feel it.

Taghazout is a Berber fishing village 19 kilometres north of [Agadir](https://derb.so/questions/why-does-agadir-look-nothing-like-other-moroccan-cities), home to the Ida Oufella tribe for centuries. Fishermen still launch blue wooden boats from the beach every morning. The original village — whitewashed walls, narrow paths, wetsuits dripping from rooftop lines — sits on a rocky headland above some of the most consistent right-hand point breaks in the Atlantic.

Surfers found it in the 1970s. Musicians found it earlier — Jimi Hendrix and the Rolling Stones passed through in the late 1960s, drawn by cheap sun and open coast. For decades it stayed small: backpackers, surf camps, a few cafés, the occasional campervan colony on the beach.

That changed. **Taghazout Bay** is Morocco's flagship coastal tourism project under the national Vision 2030 strategy. A 615-hectare development stretching south toward Tamraght has brought Fairmont, Hilton, and Riu properties. A 5-kilometre beachfront promenade connects the old village to the new resort zone. Golf courses, co-working spaces, yoga studios, vegan brunch cafés — the infrastructure of a global beach destination.

The village itself still feels like a village. The fishing boats still go out. The main street is still one road of surf shops and [tagine](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tagine) restaurants. Anchor Point — the legendary right-hander that can carry you two kilometres — still breaks the same way it always has. The surf season runs September to April, with the best swells between December and March.

What's different is the framing. Taghazout is no longer off the radar. Board rental runs about 80 MAD per day. A two-hour beginner lesson starts around €30. Accommodation ranges from 150 MAD hostel beds to €400-a-night resort rooms. The village and the resort exist side by side — two economies, two rhythms, sharing the same coastline.
The local worry isn't whether tourists come. It's whether the thing that made tourists come — the pace, the scale, the salt-air simplicity — survives the success.

shortAnswer: Taghazout is still a functioning Berber fishing village with world-class surf breaks, but major resort development (Fairmont, Hilton, Riu) has transformed the coastline south toward Tamraght. The original village and its surf culture remain intact. Surf season runs September–April, with December–March offering the best swells. Board rental around 80 MAD/day; beginner lessons from €30.

title: When is surf season in Taghazout?

sections.content: The Atlantic doesn't check a calendar, but it does have patterns.

**The main surf season runs September to April.** This is when the North Atlantic sends consistent swell to Morocco's west coast. The breaks around [Taghazout](https://derb.so/questions/is-taghazout-still-a-surf-village) — Anchor Point, Hash Point, Killer Point, Panoramas — light up with long, clean right-handers that make this coast famous.

**December through March is peak season.** The biggest and most consistent swells arrive during these months. Water temperature sits around 16–18°C — you'll want a 3/2mm wetsuit. Air temperature stays comfortable: 18–22°C during the day, dipping to 12–13°C at night. This is also when the village is busiest, with surf camps at full capacity and Anchor Point's lineup at its most crowded.

**September–November and March–April are shoulder season** — fewer people, still solid waves, warmer water. These months suit intermediate surfers who want uncrowded lineups. Summer (May–August) is flat for surfing but pleasant for swimming, beach life, and significantly cheaper accommodation.

Beginners can surf year-round at Panoramas Beach and the beach breaks closer to the village, where smaller waves are forgiving. The point breaks further north — Anchor Point, Killer Point — are for experienced surfers, especially when the swell gets overhead.

One thing the Instagram accounts won't show you: Taghazout's wind. The [Alizé trade winds](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#alize) pick up most afternoons, especially in summer. Mornings are almost always glassier. The best surfers are in the water at dawn — not for the photos, but because the wind hasn't arrived yet.

shortAnswer: Surf season runs September to April, peaking December through March with the biggest Atlantic swells. Water temperature: 16–18°C (wetsuit needed). Beginners can surf year-round on the beach breaks. Summer is flat but warm and cheap. Mornings are best — afternoon trade winds chop up the surface.

title: Is Taghazout worth visiting if you don't surf?

sections.content: You don't have to get in the water to enjoy being near it.

[Taghazout](https://derb.so/questions/is-taghazout-still-a-surf-village) built its identity on surfing, but the village works for anyone who wants a slow Atlantic coast day. The beaches — Panoramas, Taghazout Beach, the quieter stretches toward Anchor Point — are wide, clean, and uncrowded outside of peak surf season. The 5-kilometre promenade south to Tamraght is a good morning walk with the Atlas foothills rising behind you.

The café culture is genuine. Taghazout runs on *nous nous* (half espresso, half steamed milk) and has developed a brunch-and-smoothie economy alongside the traditional [tagine](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tagine) restaurants. Yoga studios and wellness retreats are everywhere — this is Morocco's centre for that particular kind of coastal wellness tourism.

Day trips fill easily. **Paradise Valley** — an hour inland — has natural rock pools set in a palm-lined canyon. The **Arganier Museum** on the road from [Agadir](https://derb.so/questions/what-is-there-to-do-in-agadir) documents the argan tree, its oil, and the women's cooperatives that produce it. The beaches north toward Cap Ghir are progressively emptier the further you go.

What Taghazout doesn't have: a [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina), historical monuments, nightlife, or much to do after dark beyond eating and watching the sunset. It's a small village. If you need cultural density, this isn't where you'll find it. If you want to sit on a terrace watching the Atlantic turn gold at 6pm, there are worse places on the planet.

shortAnswer: Yes — Taghazout works for beach walks, café culture, yoga, and day trips (Paradise Valley, argan cooperatives, empty beaches north toward Cap Ghir). What it doesn't have: a medina, monuments, or nightlife. It's a small coastal village best suited to people who want simplicity, ocean, and slow days.

title: Is Casablanca worth visiting, or should you skip it?

sections.content: Most visitors fly in and leave the same day. The guidebooks say *see the mosque, skip the rest*. Even Moroccans will tell you Casa is for work, not for wandering.

They're half right. Casablanca is not a tourist city in the way [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech) or Fes are tourist cities. It doesn't perform for visitors. It's Morocco's economic engine — the country's largest city, its commercial capital, home to roughly 4 million people in the greater metropolitan area. The pace is different. The architecture is different. The energy is work, money, ambition.

But there are things in Casablanca that exist nowhere else in Morocco. The **Hassan II Mosque** is the obvious one — the third-largest mosque in the world, built on a platform extending over the Atlantic Ocean, with a retractable roof and a minaret that stands 210 metres tall. It is one of only two mosques in Morocco that non-Muslims can enter (the other is the [Tinmel Mosque](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#tinmel) in the High Atlas, partially damaged in the [2023 earthquake](https://derb.so/questions/what-happened-2023-earthquake)). Guided tours run daily.

The **Art Deco district** — the Quartier des Habous and the downtown core around Boulevard Mohammed V — is one of the finest collections of 1930s architecture in Africa. French colonial architects experimented here with a fusion of European modernism and Moroccan decorative traditions. The buildings are deteriorating but extraordinary. The **Villa des Arts** and **Musée de la Fondation Abderrahman Slaoui** house some of Morocco's best contemporary and poster art collections.

The old medina exists but is small and unremarkable compared to Fes or Marrakech. Rick's Café exists — built in 2004 to recreate the bar from the 1942 film, which was actually shot entirely in Hollywood. It's a good piano bar. It's not history.

Casablanca rewards a day. The mosque at opening time, when the light off the ocean fills the prayer hall. Walk the Art Deco quarter. Eat in the Corniche neighbourhood overlooking the sea. Then move on — but it exists, and it matters. The Morocco of commerce and modernity is as real as the Morocco of [riads](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#riad) and [souks](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#souk).

shortAnswer: The Hassan II Mosque — one of only two Moroccan mosques open to non-Muslims — is reason enough. The 1930s Art Deco district is among the finest in Africa. Rick's Café exists but was built in 2004 as a tribute, not a relic. Casablanca isn't a tourist city. It's Morocco's economic engine, and it moves like one.

title: Why do Moroccans have mixed feelings about Casablanca?

sections.content: Ask a Moroccan from Fes about Casablanca and you'll get a polite pause. Ask someone from Marrakech and you'll get a longer one.

Casablanca is where Morocco makes its money. The Casablanca Stock Exchange, the headquarters of every major bank, the port that handles most of the country's imports and exports — it's all here. Roughly 40% of Morocco's industrial output comes from the greater Casablanca region. People move here for work the way people move to any economic capital: out of necessity, not romance.

The tension is between what Casablanca represents and what it feels like. Other Moroccan cities carry their history on their surface — the [medinas](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) of Fes and Marrakech are UNESCO World Heritage Sites, layered with centuries of visible culture. Casablanca's identity is modern, commercial, and faster-paced. The traffic is notorious. The cost of living is the highest in the country. The sense of community that defines smaller cities — where your neighbourhood [moqaddem](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#moqaddem) knows your name — thins out in a metropolis of four million.

At the same time, Casablanca is where young Moroccans build careers, where the creative economy is growing fastest, and where Morocco's global-facing ambitions are most visible. The city is investing heavily in infrastructure — the tramway, the Casablanca Finance City free zone, the new urban developments along the coast. The 2030 World Cup will bring further transformation.

Moroccans don't dislike Casablanca. They have the same relationship with it that Londoners have with London or Cairenes with Cairo — pride in its power, exhaustion from its pace, and an awareness that the soul of the country lives elsewhere.

shortAnswer: Casablanca is Morocco's economic engine — home to the stock exchange, major banks, and 40% of industrial output. Moroccans respect its power but find its pace exhausting and its identity more commercial than cultural. Other cities carry visible centuries of history; Casablanca's identity is modern. The relationship is like London to England — essential but complicated.

title: Why is Rabat so quiet compared to Marrakech?

sections.content: You step off the train expecting intensity — the noise, the density, the full-volume energy of a Moroccan city. Instead: wide avenues, trimmed hedges, a tram gliding past. You check the map. You're definitely in Morocco.

Rabat is Morocco's political capital — the seat of the King, the parliament, the ministries, the foreign embassies. It has been since 1912, when the French protectorate chose it for precisely the qualities that surprise visitors today: order, space, administrative calm. The city was designed to govern, not to sell.

The [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) exists and is lovely — smaller and more navigable than Fes or [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech), with significantly less commercial pressure. You can walk through it without being called into a shop every thirty seconds. The **Kasbah des Oudaias** — a 12th-century fortress overlooking the mouth of the Bou Regreg river — is one of the most beautiful corners of any Moroccan city: whitewashed walls, blue doors, the Andalusian garden inside, and the Atlantic stretching to the horizon.

**Chellah**, just outside the city walls, is a Roman and medieval necropolis overtaken by gardens — storks nesting on the minaret of a 14th-century mosque growing out of the ruins of a Roman town called Sala Colonia. The **Hassan Tower** — an unfinished 12th-century minaret that was intended to be the largest in the world — stands beside the modern **Mausoleum of Mohammed V**, one of Morocco's finest examples of traditional craftsmanship.

Rabat doesn't compete with Marrakech for attention and doesn't try to. There are no snake charmers, no overcrowded squares, no one pulling at your sleeve. What there is: a functioning, sophisticated city with exceptional monuments, a university district (Mohammed V University is Morocco's top-ranked), good restaurants, a growing contemporary art scene anchored by the Mohammed VI Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, and a riverside promenade where families walk at sunset.
Most tourists skip Rabat entirely. A day here — two if you're curious — shows a side of Morocco the tourist circuit never touches: the country that governs, educates, and plans its own future.

shortAnswer: It's Morocco's political capital — built for governance, not commerce. You step off the train expecting the full-volume energy of a Moroccan city. Instead: wide avenues, trimmed hedges, a tram gliding past. The medina is smaller and calmer than Marrakech's, with less commercial pressure. Most tourists skip it. A day or two reveals the Morocco that governs and plans its own future.

title: Is Rabat the capital of Morocco? Why not Casablanca or Marrakech?

sections.content: Yes. Rabat has been Morocco's capital since 1912 — and the confusion is understandable, because [Casablanca](https://derb.so/questions/is-casablanca-worth-visiting) is bigger, richer, and more famous, while [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech) gets the tourist attention.

The choice was strategic. When France established the protectorate in 1912, Resident-General Hubert Lyautey chose Rabat over the obvious alternatives. Fes was the historic imperial capital but its [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) was dense and politically volatile. Marrakech was powerful but far south. Casablanca was booming commercially but Lyautey didn't want to mix governance with commerce. Rabat — coastal, centrally located, with an existing Kasbah and room to build a modern administrative district — was the deliberate, planned choice.

Morocco has four **imperial cities** — Fes, Marrakech, Meknes, and Rabat — each of which served as the capital of a dynasty. Fes was the intellectual and spiritual centre under the Marinids. Marrakech gave its name to the country itself and was the Almoravid and Almohad capital. Meknes was Moulay Ismail's 17th-century creation. Rabat's turn came with the Almohads in the 12th century, then again with the French, and it stuck.

Today the Royal Palace in Rabat is the King's primary residence, though he has palaces in several cities. Parliament sits here. Every embassy is here. The administrative machinery of the Moroccan state runs from Rabat.

shortAnswer: Yes, Rabat has been Morocco's capital since 1912. The French chose it over Fes (politically volatile), Marrakech (too far south), and Casablanca (too commercial). Morocco has four imperial cities — Fes, Marrakech, Meknes, and Rabat — each was once a dynastic capital. Today, Casablanca is the economic capital, Marrakech the tourist capital, and Rabat the political and administrative capital.

title: What are the must-see sights in Rabat?

sections.content: Rabat doesn't overwhelm you with options. It rewards you with quality. A focused day covers the essentials; two days let you breathe.

**Kasbah des Oudaias** — The 12th-century fortress at the mouth of the Bou Regreg river is Rabat's most beautiful space. Whitewashed walls, blue-painted doors, bougainvillea cascading over stone. Inside, the Andalusian Garden — designed during the French protectorate — is one of the most peaceful corners in Morocco. The café terrace overlooking the river and the Atlantic serves [mint tea](https://derb.so/questions/why-mint-tea-tastes-different) with a view that makes you forget you're in a capital city.

**Hassan Tower and the Mausoleum of Mohammed V** — The unfinished minaret, begun in 1195 by the Almohad sultan Yacoub al-Mansour, was intended to be the tallest in the world. The earthquake of 1755 (the same one that destroyed Lisbon) reduced the attached mosque to a field of broken columns. Beside it stands the Mausoleum of Mohammed V — the grandfather of the current king — a masterwork of traditional Moroccan craftsmanship: carved plaster, [zellige](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#zellige) tilework, and cedarwood. Royal guards in white stand at the entrance.

**Chellah** — A ten-minute walk outside the city walls, this is where Roman Sala Colonia meets a 14th-century Marinid necropolis, all overtaken by gardens, cats, and nesting storks. It's one of the most atmospheric archaeological sites in Morocco — part ruin, part sanctuary, entirely unlike anything in [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech).

**Mohammed VI Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art** — Morocco's first national modern art museum, opened in 2014. Rotating exhibitions alongside a permanent collection of 20th-century Moroccan art. It's well curated and rarely crowded.

**The Medina and Rue des Consuls** — Rabat's [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina) is compact and walkable. Rue des Consuls — named for the foreign consulates that once lined it — is the main shopping street, specialising in carpets, leather, and Moroccan crafts. The hard sell here is dialled down compared to Marrakech. You can browse without battle.

shortAnswer: Kasbah des Oudaias — a 12th-century fortress with an Andalusian garden and ocean views. Hassan Tower and the Mausoleum of Mohammed V — an unfinished Almohad minaret beside a masterwork of traditional craftsmanship. Chellah — Roman-medieval ruins overtaken by gardens and storks. The Mohammed VI Museum of Modern Art. The medina is compact and relaxed, with none of the hard sell.

title: Can you go inside the Koutoubia Mosque?

sections.content: You see it from everywhere in the city. The 77-metre minaret anchors the skyline of [Marrakech](https://slowmorocco.com/places/marrakech) the way a cathedral spire anchors a European town. You walk toward it. You reach the entrance. And you stop — because you can't go in.

**No. Non-Muslims cannot enter the Koutoubia Mosque.** This is not specific to the Koutoubia — it applies to virtually every mosque in Morocco. The restriction dates to the French protectorate era, when Resident-General Hubert Lyautey issued a decree prohibiting non-Muslims from entering active mosques. The policy was intended to protect religious spaces from colonial disruption. It was never repealed, and Moroccans have maintained it as a matter of respect for sacred space.

There are only **two mosques in Morocco that non-Muslims can enter**. The first is the **Hassan II Mosque** in [Casablanca](https://derb.so/questions/is-casablanca-worth-visiting) — the third-largest mosque in the world, built on a platform extending over the Atlantic Ocean, with guided tours running daily. The second is the **Tinmel Mosque** in the High Atlas Mountains, a 12th-century Almohad masterpiece that was partially damaged in the [2023 earthquake](https://derb.so/questions/what-happened-2023-earthquake) and is undergoing restoration.

The Koutoubia itself is extraordinary from the outside. Built by the Almohad dynasty in the 12th century, its minaret set the template for the Giralda in Seville and the Hassan Tower in [Rabat](https://derb.so/questions/why-is-rabat-so-quiet). The name means *Mosque of the Booksellers* — the surrounding area was once filled with manuscript traders. The gardens around the mosque are open to everyone and are one of the best places to sit at sunset, watching the minaret catch the last light.

You'll notice the same pattern throughout Morocco. You can admire the carved cedarwood doors, the [zellige](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#zellige) tilework around the entrance, the geometry of the minarets — but the interior remains for those who pray there. The best way to understand what a Moroccan mosque looks like inside: the Hassan II is your only realistic option. It's a reason to visit [Casablanca](https://derb.so/questions/is-casablanca-worth-visiting) for that alone.

During prayer times — especially the Friday midday *salat al-Jumu'ah* — you may see the Koutoubia's doors open and worshippers spilling into the courtyard and surrounding streets. Standing respectfully at a distance is fine. Photographing people at prayer is not.

shortAnswer: No. Non-Muslims cannot enter the Koutoubia, or virtually any mosque in Morocco. Two exceptions: the Hassan II Mosque in Casablanca (guided tours daily) and the Tinmel Mosque in the High Atlas (partially damaged in the 2023 earthquake). The Koutoubia gardens are open to everyone and particularly beautiful at sunset.

title: Can you drink alcohol in Morocco?

sections.content: Yes. But the where, when, and how are specific — and getting it wrong ranges from awkward to illegal.

Morocco is a Muslim country where Islam is the state religion and the Quran prohibits alcohol. At the same time, Morocco produces its own beer, wine, and spirits, and has done so for decades. The country's five wine regions — Meknès, Rabat/Casablanca, the Eastern region, the Northern Plain, and El Jadida — produce roughly 40 million bottles a year. This coexistence is managed through licensing, discretion, and a clear set of rules.

**Where alcohol is served:** Licensed bars, licensed restaurants, licensed hotels, and your own accommodation. The key word is *licensed* — not every restaurant or [riad](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#riad) has a licence to serve alcohol, and many choose not to. Whether a riad serves alcohol is one of those things that varies property to property. In the [medina](https://slowmorocco.com/glossary#medina), the majority of traditional restaurants do not serve alcohol. Licensed restaurants tend to cluster in the *Ville Nouvelle* (new town) or in upscale tourist-facing establishments.

**Where it's sold:** Supermarkets like Carrefour and Atacadão have dedicated alcohol sections — usually a separate room or entrance within the store. Licensed liquor stores (*magasins*) exist in larger cities: Marrakech, [Casablanca](https://derb.so/questions/is-casablanca-worth-visiting), [Rabat](https://derb.so/questions/why-is-rabat-so-quiet), [Agadir](https://derb.so/questions/why-does-agadir-look-nothing-like-other-moroccan-cities), Fes, Tangier. In the medina itself, you will rarely find alcohol for sale. In rural areas and smaller towns, availability drops sharply — if you're heading to the desert or the mountains, buy before you leave the city.

**Where you cannot drink:** On the street. In public parks. On public transport. At the beach (with rare exceptions in Agadir's tourist zone). Public drinking is illegal and can result in a fine or arrest. Licensed bars in Morocco often have no street-facing windows — this is by design, not coincidence. Discretion is structural.

**What's available:** Morocco's three main beers — Casablanca (the best), Flag Spéciale (pilsner), and Stork (light lager) — are all produced by Société des Brasseries du Maroc, owned by Heineken. Moroccan wines, particularly reds from the Meknès region, are genuinely good and increasingly recognised internationally. Grey wine — Morocco's variation on rosé — is distinctive. International spirits are available in licensed venues. Prices are higher than you might expect: beer runs 50–80 MAD in a restaurant, wine 50–100 MAD per glass, cocktails 100–180 MAD. Alcohol is heavily taxed.

**During [Ramadan](https://derb.so/questions/what-is-ramadan):** Alcohol sales are restricted or suspended in many places. Some licensed hotels and tourist restaurants continue to serve discreetly, but availability shrinks significantly. Finding a drink during the holy month becomes genuinely difficult.

**A note on riads:** Not all riads serve alcohol. Some have licences; many don't. Some are happy for you to bring your own; others would prefer you didn't. Some guests ask their host when they book. If your riad doesn't serve alcohol and you'd like wine for your stay, most people pick it up at a supermarket or bring a bottle in luggage — Morocco allows up to one litre of spirits and one litre of wine per person at customs.

The unwritten rule underneath all of this: Morocco accommodates alcohol without celebrating it. Alcohol is available. Discretion is the local custom. And if someone offers you *Berber whisky*, smile — it's [mint tea](https://derb.so/questions/why-mint-tea-tastes-different).

shortAnswer: Legal, available, but not everywhere. Licensed bars, restaurants, hotels, and private accommodation serve it. Public drinking is illegal. Not all riads have licences. Supermarkets in larger cities stock beer, wine, and spirits. Availability thins in medinas, rural areas, and during Ramadan. Morocco produces its own beer (Casablanca, Flag, Stork) and wine from five regions. Discretion is the local custom.
